qas.question: Who largely formalized the developments that led to the theory of conservation of energy?
What aided the rapid development of explanations of chemical processes by Clausius, Gibbs and Nernst?
Who developed the concept of the introduction of laws of radiant energy?
What states that the conservation of energy is a consequence of the fact that the laws of physics do not change over time?
Who largely rejected the developments that led to the theory of conservation of energy?
What hindered the rapid development of explanations of chemical processes by Clausius, Gibbs and Nernst?
Who developed the concept of the introduction of laws of stored energy?
What states that the conservation of energy is a consequence of the fact that the laws of physics change over time?

plausible_answers.text: direct mathematical consequence of the translational symmetry of the quantity conjugate to energy, namely time

qas.question: since 1819, theorists have understood that the law of conservation of energy is what?

context: These developments led to the theory of conservation of energy, formalized largely by <a0_0><b4_0>William Thomson<b4_0/><a0_0/> (Lord Kelvin) as the field of thermodynamics. <a1_0><b5_0>Thermodynamics<b5_0/><a1_0/> aided the rapid development of explanations of chemical processes by Rudolf Clausius, Josiah Willard Gibbs, and Walther Nernst. It also led to a mathematical formulation of the concept of entropy by Clausius and to the introduction of laws of radiant energy by <a2_0><b6_0>Jožef Stefan<b6_0/><a2_0/>. According to <a3_0><b7_0>Noether's theorem<b7_0/><a3_0/>, the conservation of energy is a consequence of the fact that the laws of physics do not change over time. Thus, since 1918, theorists have understood that the law of conservation of energy is the <b8_0>direct mathematical consequence of the translational symmetry of the quantity conjugate to energy, namely time<b8_0/>.
